comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
En esta foto se ve a la extrema derecha a Don Francisco I. Madero, detrás de él Rodolfo Fierro, marcado con X Pascual Orozco (hijo), y a su derecha Abraham González; arriba del copyright Bain aparece Pascual Orozco (padre).  El resto aun no los identifico. 
Al triunfo de la Revolución Maderista,  Pascual Orozco ambicionaba la gubernatura de Chihuahua, que la obtuvo Abraham González, o la Secretaría de Guerra que se le otorgó a Venustiano Carranza. 
Al extremo derecho de la foto se aprecia el número 2324-3, de acuerdo a éste número, correspondería a algún dia de marzo de 1911, antes de la Toma de Ciudad Juárez.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: jerodamor@yahoo.com.mx: thank you for your identifications of some of the men in this photograph.  We will add the information to the record when we update.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
This picture must have been taken by March 24-26, 1911 after the arrival of Mr. Francisco I. Madero (Jefe Supremo de [todas] las Fuerzas  Revolucionarias) to Bustillos Hacienda . (Pedro Salmerón mentions that the arrival was on March 24 and the stay was during two weeks).
Amaya quoted by Salmerón says that the nomination (Jefe de la Revolución en Chihuahua) was given to José Perfecto Lomelí by Madero staying in Texas. Lomelí declined on José de la Luz Soto. When Madero crossed the border into Mexico (on the evening 13-14 Fefruary, 1911, by Isleta, near Zaragoza de Bravos) realized the mistaken nomination and recognized Pascual Orozco Jr, who in fact, was already acting like the Chief of the Revolution in Chihuahua
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Dr. Robert Duarte: Thank you for your information on the date of this image.  We will add it to the  description when we update.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
I found this picture printed on The El Paso Herald issue April 24, 1912 (Cronicling America, The Library of Congress) [That's more than one year beyond the dates metioned above]. Above is written:  "When Orozco signed proclamation of Independence of Chihuahua from Madero Rule."
Dr. Roberto Duarte.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
Found an article in El Paso Herald, issue April 8, 1911 (The Library of Congress, Cronicling America) entiled "CHIHUAHUA STREETS ARE ALL FORTIFIED", in the second paragraph you
can read:   "Madero and Orozco had been at Bustillos, 60 miles west of Chihuahua with 1200 men, for nearly two weeks [that is about March 25], unmolested.  Many news men, photographers have been entertained by them.  Their pictures now adorn one side of several thousand new postal cards in Chihuahua"
Friederich Katz in his "Pancho Villa" writes that Madero left Bustillos on April 7, 1911, towards north to siege Juárez, There went three collumns  the first two, one under Orozco and the other under Villa, and behind them, the third under Madero himself with 1500 men.
Dr. Roberto Duarte
Plastic Surgeon

comment.author: 53461717@N08
53461717@N08
comment._content: Found photos www.inehrm.gob.mx/imagenes/planempacad/13.jpg and www.inehrm.gob.mx/imagenes/planempacad/14.jpg that surely are a secuence of this picture One says it was taken at El Vergel, the other is dated on 3.6.12 (March 6, 1912) Then who is the short framed man to the left of Pascual Orozco? Madero by then was Constitutional President of trhe Mexican Republic, and on March 6, 1912, Orozco launched his rebelion against Madero. See in this collection Orozco enters Chihuahua #1 & #2 which are dated on that day. El Vergel is a few hundred miles south to Chihuahua City ?????? Orozco was proclaimed by Madero supreme chief of the revolutionary forces to Chihuahua by April 1911 which is the most likely date of the three pictures. Abraham González was not a rebel against Madero. If the picture was taken during Orozco rebelion, what is doing González in these three pictures? Dr. Roberto Duarte
